p: Health authorities and researchers, from international to local levels, recognize the serious threats to health that climate change poses and are taking protective measures to reduce current impacts and future risks [ 8]. Evidence-based information about current and possible future risks to health, vulnerable populations, and effective adaptation options is needed so as to prepare individuals and communities for the health impacts of climate change [ 9, 10]. This includes identification of innovative adaptations for use by public health officials to understand and respond to more severe and possibly compounding effects of future climate change, such as threats from tipping points and shock events that are outside of the range of current experience [ 11].
